source: Refined after empirical testing with Suno-generated lyrics

lyricAlternatives: what the person does, not what they feel
rules.notes: Triggers generic love song vocabulary. Replace with specific showing, not telling. Instead of 'I love you', show what love looks like in this specific situation.

lyricAlternatives: what the body does under emotion
rules.notes: Triggers predictable rhyme pairs and abstract emotional vocabulary. Ground in physical sensation instead.
Triggers generic pop/R&B patterns. Specific names or relationship context create distinction.

lyricAlternatives: specific time reference (til the streetlights come on)
physical duration (til the rust takes the car)
rules.notes: Abstract eternal time is generic. Specific, limited time references are more powerful and honest.
Like 'forever', abstract always triggers generic patterns. Specificity adds credibility.

lyricAlternatives: specific aspiration (that house on the corner)
action toward goal, not goal itself
rules.notes: Abstract dreams trigger vague imagery. Concrete dreams (specific house, job, moment) have power.

lyricAlternatives: action during grief (calling no one back)
what the room looks like during breakdown
rules.notes: Tears are telling, not showing. Physical details of grief are more effective.
Abstract soul triggers philosophical cliche. Ground in specific internal experience.

lyricAlternatives: the reckless action, not the feeling
rules.notes: Fire/desire is the most predictable rhyme pair in English. Avoid completely or use slant rhyme.

lyricAlternatives: what you're doing specifically at night
rules.notes: Night/light is predictable. Specific night details (sounds, light quality, activities) are better.

lyricAlternatives: specific weather detail (the smell before rain)
what rain sounds like on specific surface
rules.notes: Rain as sadness metaphor is exhausted. Specific rain details or subverting the metaphor work better.

lyricAlternatives: what the eyes do (squint, avoid, search)
specific eye behavior (the way they drop)
rules.notes: Eyes as beauty marker is generic. Eye behavior or specific details create character.
Generic sky triggers generic imagery. Specific skies (time, weather, contents) have distinction.
Sun as positive/hope is predictable. Specific sun moments or subversion work better.

triggeredCliches: by the light of the moon
rules.notes: Moon/June is the classic cliche rhyme. Any use requires intentional approach.

lyricAlternatives: time in objects (the calendar we never changed)
rules.notes: Abstract time is vague. Specific time markers ground the song in reality.

country.note: These are expected but oversaturated. Use sparingly with specific detail.

pop.note: Functional genre words. Avoid stacking multiple in same verse.

hipHop.note: Authenticity markers become cliche when overused. Earn each use.

indie.note: Aesthetic markers. One per song maximum.

alternatives: specific physical manifestation of suppressed emotion
what the body does when holding it in
stockPhrases.notes: Every song about hidden pain uses this exact phrase. Show don't tell.

alternatives: the thing you'd do if they left
stockPhrases.notes: States desire directly. Show what wanting distance looks like.
Generic memory complaint. Make the haunting specific.
Overused intensity marker. Find a fresh metaphor for devastation.

alternatives: what the eyes are doing specifically
stockPhrases.notes: Vague romantic gesture. Make the looking specific.
Abstract violence metaphor. Ground in physical reality.
States the problem. Show the holding instead.
Lazy fate invocation. Earn the sense of destiny through specifics.

lazyRhymePairs.notes: These words cluster together constantly. Using any two triggers cliche. If you use 'fire', find a slant rhyme.
Death-interior cluster. 'Inside' almost always leads to 'died' or 'alive'.
Motion-time cluster. Very common, not always avoidable, but be intentional.
The original cliche rhyme. Any of these together triggers immediate recognition.

gerundGerund.problem: Shared suffix, not real sonic relationship. Same semantic field makes it worse.

sameSemanticField.problem: No contrast. Rhyme should create unexpected connection, not confirm the obvious.

suffixOnly.pattern: Rhyme only in suffix, not root
suffixOnly.problem: Grammatical rhyme, not sonic. Feels like accident.

bridgeEqualsVerse.pattern: Bridge content identical or near-identical to a verse
bridgeEqualsVerse.problem: Not a bridge at all. Bridge must shift perspective, time, or speaker.
bridgeEqualsVerse.fix: Ask: what hasn't been said yet? Say that in the bridge.

chorusExpansion.pattern: Chorus adds lines on later repeats without development
chorusExpansion.problem: More words â‰  more meaning. Padding disguised as development.
chorusExpansion.fix: Each chorus iteration should recontextualize through what came before, not through added words.

hookWithoutExploration.pattern: Title/hook phrase repeated but never unpacked
hookWithoutExploration.problem: We hear it but never learn what it means to the speaker.
hookWithoutExploration.fix: Verses should show us different facets of the hook's meaning.

noArc.pattern: Speaker's emotional state identical at end and beginning
noArc.problem: Nothing happened. Why did we listen?
noArc.fix: Something must change: realization, acceptance, escalation, or collapse.
